comments.commentBody: Apparently the Russians have done more to vet our candidates for high office -- Trump, his staff, family, and Cabinet appointees -- than the Republican Senate? From Russia with love!
Yarbrough belongs in jail.

The Curious World of Donald Trump’s Private Russian Connections
http://www.the-american-interest.com/2016/12/19/the-curious-world-of-don...

This was a nice workout. I was happy to see both SHIRLEY CHISHOLM nd Phil OCHS in the puzzle. Here's my favorite Phil Ochs song from my favorite Phil Ochs album:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BWt_CAtPFXY

Had that album but misplaced it somewhere along the way.

I believe I still have 'Rehearsals for Retirement' in storage, but I've been known to be wrong about stuff like that before.
Tape From California was my fist cassette tape.  It's long gone.

Follow the (BIG) money- it's what Trump and a number of his associates and their Russki counterparts have in common - disdain for rules, and desire for immense wealth. Determination to maximize their 'opportunities' while Trump has power.

Sessions, despite being in the middle , may have much less to do with all this than the shadow government - Bannon, Kushner. ( to my mind, Sessions was gloating over his final triumph over past enemies, and the opportunity to take the DOJ back to the 50's).

Trump's early appointment of Manafort was an obvious clue to the not-so-hidden intent of this administration. The trumpies may indeed not "know" anything about the hacking - they simply don't care because protecting this country's voting and legal system is not their priority. Keeping Trump's taxes and interlinked ownership agreements secret - that comes first.

It may not show much of anything -- but those tax records ought to be released. maybe someone could bribe a Russian to do it?

Understand. Should point out that Trump's election heist was enabled by the GOP's systematic campaign to disenfranchise voters by the millions. Citizen's United enabled dark money to poor into states and ensure--with gerrymandering (Operation Redmap) that Republicans would be in charge and control 70% of the E.C. as a fall-back. The list of thuggering-type tactics is long which makes me wonder did the Russians obtain some worthwhile dirt when they hacked the RNC's public and private servers? I'm ready to bet.

FYI: High Sierra is a fab golden oldie movie directed by Raoul Walsh starring Bogie & Lupino. One of the ones they don't make 'em like anymore. Available for download for your viewing pleasure at Pirate Bay.

That was my first thought for that answer as well.

It's only appeared in a puzzle once before (in 1984) and was clued as "Bogart film: 1941."

Forget about Sessions' little lies in his hearing. That's small ball.

The big picture is that various members of the Trump campaign, including his son-in-law and people who would later be appointed to key positions in the Administration, met with Russian diplomats (and who knows what other Russians) during a time when the Russian government was hacking the DNC, working with Julian Assange to release the stolen information, and continuing to openly mock us by harboring a treasonous traitor (Snowden) who stole massive amounts of information from our government about our intelligence gathering apparatus.

Is there anybody within the GOP who has the honor, dignity and ethical compass to admit this needs to be investigated? For heavens' sake, Obama and Hillary were under a barrage of investigations for eight years for far less.

Maybe Trump can unleash the guys who spent all those years "investigating" the Obama birther claims and Vince Foster murder conspiracies. They should have some free time now to look into this.
The F.B.I. went on a fishing trip and disappeared.

"Maybe Trump can unleash the guys who spent all those years "investigating" the Obama birther claims and Vince Foster murder conspiracies. They should have some free time now to look into this."

I don't know. They may well still be working on that.

If the Russian contacts were, "no big deal," why lie about it? At some point the straight-up denials, when refuted, have to be treated as evidence of something much more sinister.

The bottom line is that no one in the current administration can be trusted because they are simply unable to tell the truth when every other word out of their leader Is a lie.
EVERY person supporting a liar can't love the trueth very much..
Who sold uranium to the Russians again??
Why wasn't Sergey thrown out by Obama?

They have been claiming that. Trump has to because he needs to claim that the "improved" economy is all because of him. Even in December he claimed credit for the employment numbers; he has claimed the stock market. The truth is that the economy has been improving for years albeit too slowly.
Right. Obama, though, did "inherit a mess" but never whined that. HE simply got to work.

Anyone who has the support of fellow Senate Republicans is automatically suspect in my book. As a group they are despicable and contemptible. More so Jeff Sessions because he is also a racist and a liar.

Walker's "accomplishments" in Wisconsin (from NON-liberal sources):
* 50th in the US in Short Term Job Growth - U.S. Chamber of Commerce
* 49th in Economic Outlook - Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia
* 49th in Job Growth through 2016 - Forbes Magazine
* 45th in the Nation in Wage Growth - Bureau of Labor Statistics
* 44th in the Nation in Job Growth - Bureau of Labor Statistics
* 42nd Best State for Business - Forbes magazine

The title of the Eliot volume (now usually given as Poems 2) is not Latin. It was far enough from Latin to prompt me to do a little research.

Eliot's title (originally mistakenly "Ara vus prec") is a half-line from Dante (who was writing in medieval Italian), quoting the poet Arnaut Daniel (12th c.) who is himself speaking in his own Provençal. A linguistic oddity to say the least.

Ara vos prec, per aquella valor
que vos guida al som de l’escalina,
sovenha vos a temps de ma dolor!

I'm so glad, David, that you contributed your information in multiple posts so that I could give you multiple recommendations.

Bravo!
(Thanks, DL. Me like language.)
Me figured that out.
Many Americans think about the things you mention, Louise. They just aren't the Russian, oops I mean American, people who are currently in charge.

It was a classic double-cross! Putin with superior planning, skillfully plotted meaningless events to appear as a patterned narrative. His advanced outline observed and identified the behaviors it would take to distract Trump and tie his administration in knots--knowing Trump would dig deeper holes of skepticism with each denial/lie, each protest/deflection.

These are not Hillary's emails. This is a pattern of engaging Russian officials in conversations about state business--including sanctions!--before the administration was installed; it is about a pervasive pattern of denials that turn out to be true! It is about a corrupt process and a lack of accountability, no matter what the facts are.

Trump, too busy preening over his fall victory and the size of his crowds, too busy reviewing press releases for the best photo-op for industrial plants already built (Boeing) or planned (Intel), has never grasped governing is a process--details and procedures matter. (See the utter failure of his executive order on immigration! He took legitimate powers and went outside the lines.)

Now he wants to separate mothers from children at the border. His "security" will not make this country safe. It diminishes its reputation and global standing daily. Creating a new arms race makes him look like a mad man out of control, driven by a hubris of pride and vanity.

He retains 1000s of enablers, voters, voices (the lone racists at Walmarts) he think white is right and his cruel hate is great!

Putin knew a man and his team busy inventing and manufacturing conspiracies at every turn would not be able to see a real one right before their eyes--with themselves at the center--played against each other.

Your scenarios 1 & 2 point to the dangers of having such a preponderance of people in the Trump crowd who appear to be blinded by a single focus on securing maximum personal financial profit (with little apparent regard for any human costs in adopting such a strategy) and by their apparent total ineptness and incompetence at anything other than securing "deals" that benefit themselves.  Such people are both unlikely to notice (or, if they do, to care) if those they're interacting with are benefiting in ways potentially damaging to others, including the people of the U.S..    They appear to be precisely the kind of people that Campaigner Trump derided and demonized as being responsible for the loss of US manufacturing jobs and the failure to pay US taxes and this campaign stance appears to have been a principal reason for his election victory.  Has an electorate ever been so clearly duped?

Louise, as you are from the UK it is understandable how you could find the apparent situation so difficult to believe. If you forget for a moment your respect for my country and consider its politicians as nothing more than people like those in any other country (even yours), you will no doubt remember that throughout history politicians have done despicable, traitorous, disreputable things for sinister reasons, even when they tell themselves they're doing the "right thing."

Our politicians are some of the worst in that they are elected by the people to serve the nation, and take an oath which they sometimes immediately violate. In our present predicament, the Republican Party has allowed a faction within it to steer the Party toward an abyss in which the Party is more important than the country it is supposed to serve. If our Congress was filled with a dictator's appointees they could almost be excused for serving the wrong master; ours utterly refuse to acknowledge their first priority and instead display complete contempt for those they serve.

The political history of the United States contains countless incidents of politicians, from presidents on down, who violated the People's trust. Many have been dealt with harshly, as they should be. This process will hopefully weed out the untrustworthy elements within our government and restore the faith the People should have in it.

Do NOT give money to panhandlers. Instead, give it to nonprofits in your area that help the homeless.

Many panhandlers are frauds, just using their spare time to make money before returning to their warm homes. Others use the money to support their drug habit. Others are mentally ill, but by choice not getting treatment. Homelessness agencies deal with their clients to provide homes, with rules, in exchange for requirements for treatment of addiction and mental illness.

Sorry, Papa, not infallible on this one!
I'm glad you offered an alternative along with the usual cautions. As someone who has hesitated out of conventional cautions, I feel the message Pope Francis sent was   a much-needed counterweight.

You have to start by understanding who benefits most from your gift. You can give to nonprofits for sure. But the greatest personal blessing comes from giving directly to another person. And of course you can always do both.
What evidence do you have that panhandlers are frauds?  It seems like there are asier ways to get a few bucks that standing on the corner shaking a can.

Trump is a bad liar and demands everybody to buy his mendacity. Last month he said at a news conference: "I own nothing in Russia. I have no loans in Russia. I don’t have any deals in Russia." But his eldest son, Donald Jr said in 2008 that the family businesses “see a lot of money pouring in from Russia." For this reason Trump has refused to release his tax returns.
Then Trump said he had “nothing to do with Russia,” and that “to the best of my knowledge, no person that I deal with does.” But a number of his advisers have had links with Russia. Obviously Trump had something going on in Russia that may be a burden to his presidency. As he is desperate to hide it from the public he sees lying as a prize worth paying for.
Unlike Chuck Schumer's alleged contact with Putin, which will withstand public scrutiny, Trump adopts a pattern of categorical denial of all ties to Russia - even in trivial matters. He fears that once admitting an innocuous contact, it would spark a flurry of investigation. But he underestimates people with critical minds, and the consequences of once proven guilty of lying.

Sheer rubbish and if son has/had any dealings in Russia so what ?Russia is a major country encompassing 1/5 of Earth's land and despite some sanctions is part of the WTO. He has stated he has no deals in Russia with no loans either so where is the proof he does?. Here's what you should know that our government just like Russia spies and tries to influence other countries else you forgot how we hacked Merkel's and Bibi's personal cell phones and their our main allies. Where is the crime and what is the crime?.
Pope Francis is a remarkable human being.
The more I learn about this Pope the more I like him.

While Pope Francis is hitting all the right notes generally I don't think he is right about this. Homelessness and begging are symptoms of inadequate income, marginalization if the mentally ill and addicted, systematic discrimination and similar societal ills. Proper taxation and social expenditures would do a lot to alleviate most of this blight. To throw a buck or two at someone to make them go away and to rinse your conscience of guilt for a few minutes is poor policy and avoids the real work of solving the actual problems. Do the real job of raising taxes, improving public education, drug programs, family planning, decent public housing and the begging will diminish and public space will be far more pleasant than it is now.

And really WORK (not just opine) for those things of which you speak to become government policy.

But since those things aren't happening, right now, for the poor soul on the sidewalk in front of you, give if you can. Not complicated. That's all.

Remember, "there but for the grace of God, go I".  Your truly intellectual, economic analysis somehow lacks the appreciation of the status, intellectual, economic, of someone in the position of asking for assistance.  Christ didn't ask people to help those in need only if there weren't adequate incomes available nor if the society had poor policies, but if there was need.  Try to earn a living as a cynic by relying on the help of strangers and see what's it's really like.
Maybe this works in Canada. I don't think it works here in the blessed U.S., particularly impoverished New Mexico, especially Albuquerque, where off ramps and medians are loaded with panhandlers.
Grazie Papa Francis.

What a wonderful message. From the Pope and the Times.

This same compassion should infuse our social programs at home and our foreign aid abroad. We should provide healthcare and good education for all. Without exception and without means testing. Stinginess shouldn't enter in.

Whether you're religious or not, did you know the Bible urges what's called a Jubilee year, where debts are forgiven. And urges its readers to "care for the alien among you" - reminding us that we too, in terms of our ancestors, were once aliens.

There are so many ways to be compassionate. Sometimes what you give away can feel so much more meaningful than what you keep for yourself or expect payment in return. Even a smile can be a gift.

What an uplifting Editorial!

An "uplifting editorial" indeed.  I carry some bills with me for quick access when I am on the streets of NYC.  Many who ask are not "frauds" and what matters most is the good will of the giver, not the need of the recipient. Believers know that.
